newsitem.title: USA: U.S. West spot power flat ahead of holiday.
newsitem.headline: U.S. West spot power flat ahead of holiday.

text.p: Western U.S. spot electricity prices were quoted notionally in line with Monday levels since daily scheduling through Thursday was finished at the beginning of the week, market sources said Tuesday.
Traders noted that abundant hydroelectric supplies, despite some flood control constraints in the Pacific Northwest, were putting downward pressure on prices.

"There is pressure on backing thermals off," said one trader. No thermal generation units have been completely shut due to the market, but many plants are cycling down during off-peak hours, he added.
Firm, peak electricity at the California-Oregon border (COB) for Thursday was quoted at $13.50-14.50 per megawatt hour (MWh), while off-peak was bid as low as $8.00.
Thursday firm, peak power at Mid-Columbia (Mid-C) was quoted at $13.00-$15.00, while off-peak was quoted at $9.50-11.50.
Firm, peak Palo Verde (PV) electricity for Thursday was quoted at $13.00-14.50, while off-peak was at $8.00-9.00.
Thursday firm, peak prices at Four Corners were quoted at $13.00-15.00, with off-peak at $8.00-9.00.
